note: KS1/2 clusters follow NC programme of study granularity closely. KS3 domains with many concepts (Number, Algebra, Geometry) are split into 4-6 clusters using co_teach_hints as the primary grouping signal. KS4 domains are compact by design (GCSE subject content), so 2-3 clusters each. Y1 Fractions has only 2 concepts with no meaningful sub-split so treated as a single practice cluster. Several single-concept KS2 domains (Y4-D002, Y4-D007, Y4-D008, Y5-D002, Y5-D005, Y5-D007, Y5-D008) are given a single practice cluster. Y6-D004 Ratio has one concept and one cluster.

clusters.cluster_name: Understand and use the counting sequence to 100

thinking_lenses.rationale: The counting sequence is defined by a repeating positional pattern: each number follows the previous by exactly one unit, and skip-counting in 2s, 5s and 10s reveals regular arithmetic patterns that pupils can predict and extend.

clusters.rationale: Counting forwards/backwards and counting in multiples of 2, 5 and 10 are the twin foundations of all number work in Year 1. Both co_teach_hints link them to each other and to grouping/sharing, confirming they belong together as the entry point to the domain.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math K.CC.A - Know number names and the count sequence

clusters.cluster_name: Read, write and represent numbers to 100

thinking_lenses.rationale: Numeral and word representations follow systematic base-10 patterns — recognising that 'thirty-seven' encodes the same structural pattern as 'twenty-three' allows pupils to generalise across the whole decade sequence.

clusters.rationale: Reading and writing numerals and words are complementary encoding/decoding skills. C004 co_teaches with C003, confirming natural pairing.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math K.CC.A.3 - Write numbers from 0 to 20

clusters.cluster_name: Compare, order and place numbers on a number line

thinking_lenses.rationale: Ordering numbers and using one more/one less builds the foundational insight that the number line is a regular, predictable structure where position encodes magnitude.
Placing numbers on a number line introduces proportional reasoning about relative size — deciding where 47 sits between 0 and 100 requires judging magnitude, not just counting.

clusters.rationale: One more/one less, number line positioning and comparison language all contribute to the same mathematical idea: understanding relative magnitude. C006 and C007 mutually co-teach; C005 co-teaches with C006, confirming the cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 1.NBT.B.3 - Compare two two-digit numbers using >, =, < symbols

clusters.cluster_name: Understand addition and subtraction as operations

thinking_lenses.rationale: Addition and subtraction are causal operations: combining two groups causes a predictable increase, and removing a quantity causes a predictable decrease — establishing this cause-and-effect logic is the core cognitive work of the cluster.
The inverse relationship between addition and subtraction is a fundamental pattern that pupils begin to see here — what one operation does, the other undoes.

clusters.rationale: Establishing the conceptual meaning of both operations (combining/augmenting; taking away/difference) is the essential first move. Both concepts are mutually listed in co_teach_hints.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 1.OA.A - Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction

clusters.cluster_name: Know number bonds and solve missing number problems within 20

thinking_lenses.rationale: Number bonds reveal the complementary pattern of a given total — knowing that 7 + 3 = 10 immediately implies 3 + 7, 10 - 3, and 10 - 7, training pupils to see a family of related facts.
Missing number problems make the causal structure of addition and subtraction explicit: pupils reason about what value must have caused the given result, applying if-then logic.

clusters.rationale: Fluent number bonds are the knowledge base; missing number problems are the application. Both co-teach with the operation concepts and with each other.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 1.OA.C.6 - Add and subtract within 20

clusters.cluster_name: Explore grouping, sharing, doubling and halving

thinking_lenses.rationale: Doubling and halving are the first multiplicative relationships pupils encounter — grouping equal sets into a total and sharing a total into equal parts are the two inverse proportional actions that underpin all later multiplication and division.
Equal groups reveal the regular pattern that underlies multiplication: each group adds the same quantity, and doubling consistently scales any number by a factor of two.

clusters.rationale: Grouping/sharing and doubling/halving are the two foundational lenses on multiplicative structure. C013 co_teaches with C012 directly. Only two concepts, so no introduction/practice split is warranted.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.OA.C - Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication

clusters.cluster_name: Recognise and find halves and quarters of shapes and quantities

thinking_lenses.rationale: Finding one half and one quarter introduces the idea that a whole can be divided into equal parts — this is the entry point for all proportional reasoning about part-whole relationships.

clusters.rationale: One half and one quarter are introduced together as the first fraction pair; C014 and C015 are mutually co-taught and together complete the Year 1 fractions curriculum. Only two concepts; a single cluster is appropriate.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 1.G.A.3 - Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares

clusters.cluster_name: Compare and measure length, mass and capacity

thinking_lenses.rationale: Comparing and measuring length, mass and capacity are all about reasoning with quantity — pupils learn that objects can be ordered by magnitude and that non-standard then standard units provide a common scale for comparison.

Each continuous attribute (length, mass, capacity) has a structural property that determines how it is measured — understanding what makes one thing heavier or longer than another connects the physical structure to the measurement outcome.

clusters.rationale: The three continuous quantity measures are all introduced via the same pedagogical sequence (direct comparison → non-standard → standard units). C016, C017 and C018 are mutually co-taught, forming a natural teaching unit.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 1.MD.A - Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units

clusters.cluster_name: Sequence events and tell the time to the hour and half past

thinking_lenses.rationale: The clock face encodes a regular cyclical pattern — hours repeat every 12, and half past is always halfway round; recognising this pattern underpins all subsequent time-telling work.
Sequencing events before/after and relating half past to the half-way position on the clock introduces the idea of time as a quantity that can be measured and ordered.

clusters.rationale: Time is a distinct strand within Measurement with its own vocabulary and representation. Its single concept stands alone as a cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 1.MD.B.3 - Tell and write time in hours and half-hours

clusters.cluster_name: Recognise and know the value of coins and notes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Understanding that a 50p coin is worth more than a 10p coin, and that combinations of smaller coins can equal one larger coin, is an early application of reasoning about relative quantity and value.

clusters.rationale: Money is a distinct applied context within Measurement. Recognising coins and notes is a knowledge-based prerequisite cluster before calculation work begins in Year 2.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.MD.C.8 - Solve problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies

clusters.cluster_name: Recognise and name common 2-D and 3-D shapes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Recognising shapes by name is the first step in understanding how a shape's structural properties — the number and type of its sides or faces — define what it is and distinguish it from other shapes.

clusters.rationale: 2-D and 3-D shape recognition are explicitly co-taught (each concept lists the other) and together complete the Year 1 shape curriculum. A single cluster is appropriate for just two paired concepts.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math K.G.A.1 - Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes

clusters.cluster_name: Describe position and movement using spatial and directional language

thinking_lenses.rationale: Spatial and directional language (above, below, left, right, forwards, turn) encodes the structural relationships between objects in space — pupils use these terms to describe how position and orientation change.

clusters.rationale: Spatial language and turn language are taught together; C024 co-teaches with C023. Both concepts anchor real-world spatial reasoning in Year 1.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math K.G.A.1 - Describe relative positions of objects

clusters.cluster_name: Extend the counting sequence and recognise odd and even numbers

thinking_lenses.rationale: Skip-counting in 2s, 3s and 5s and the odd/even classification both rest on recognising regular patterns in the number sequence — odd and even alternate without exception, and each skip-count sequence follows a fixed step that pupils can predict forward and backward.

clusters.rationale: Counting in steps of 2, 3 and 5 and recognising odd/even are mutually co-taught and share the same structural insight about the number system. Establishes the entry point for Year 2 number work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.OA.C.3 - Determine whether a group of objects has an odd or even number

clusters.cluster_name: Understand place value in two-digit numbers

thinking_lenses.rationale: Two-digit place value is a positional pattern: the tens digit follows a regular rule (each ten-group contains exactly ten ones), and pupils use this pattern to partition, compare and order any two-digit number.
Understanding that 10 ones make one ten introduces the multiplicative scaling at the heart of our number system — the tens column represents quantities ten times as large as the ones column.

clusters.rationale: Understanding tens and ones is the prerequisite for comparing and ordering to 100 using < > = symbols. C002 co-teaches with C003.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.NBT.A - Understand place value

clusters.cluster_name: Order and arrange numbers and objects in patterns and sequences

thinking_lenses.rationale: This cluster is explicitly about pattern recognition — pupils must identify the repeating or growing rule in sequences of numbers and objects, then use that rule to extend or complete the pattern.

clusters.rationale: Pattern and sequence work is a distinct strand in the NC that crosses number and shape. Placed here as a standalone practice cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.OA.D.9 - Identify arithmetic patterns

clusters.cluster_name: Recall and use addition and subtraction facts to 20 and 100

thinking_lenses.rationale: Number fact fluency is built on recognising the complementary pattern within each number bond family — knowing 6 + 4 = 10 immediately activates 4 + 6, 10 - 4, and 10 - 6, so one fact unlocks four.
Adding or subtracting a number causes a predictable change in the total — fluent recall of these facts allows pupils to reason about what operation was applied without counting.

clusters.rationale: Fluent recall of number facts and the procedural skill of adding/subtracting two-digit numbers are tightly linked (C004 and C005 mutually co-teach). This pairing drives fluency across the rest of the domain.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.OA.B.2 - Fluently add and subtract within 20

clusters.cluster_name: Understand properties and relationships of addition and subtraction

thinking_lenses.rationale: The four operations follow consistent patterns and rules (commutativity, distributivity, inverse relationships) that pupils recognise across different number types.
Each operation enacts a causal transformation: adding causes an increase, multiplying by a factor causes proportional growth — understanding this causality deepens fluency.

clusters.rationale: Commutativity, associativity and the inverse relationship are the conceptual scaffolding that underlies mental calculation strategies. C006 co-teaches with C007.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 1.OA.B.3 - Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract

clusters.cluster_name: Recall the 2, 5 and 10 times tables and write multiplication and division statements

thinking_lenses.rationale: Times tables are the clearest arithmetic patterns in KS1 — the 2s always end in 0, 2, 4, 6, 8; the 5s always end in 0 or 5; the 10s always end in 0. These regularities help pupils internalise and verify facts.

Writing multiplication and division statements formally encodes the proportional relationship between groups, group size and total — 5 × 3 = 15 and 15 ÷ 3 = 5 describe the same multiplicative structure.

clusters.rationale: Table recall and writing formal multiplication/division statements (using × and ÷) are taught together as the formal entry into multiplicative arithmetic. C008 and C009 mutually co-teach.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.OA.C.7 - Fluently multiply and divide within 100

clusters.cluster_name: Understand commutativity of multiplication and non-commutativity of division

thinking_lenses.rationale: Commutativity is a structural pattern of the operation itself — 3 × 5 = 5 × 3 always holds for multiplication but never for division, making this a key moment for pupils to notice how the pattern depends on the operation.

Understanding that reversing the order of factors has no effect on the product (but reversing dividend and divisor does change the quotient) trains pupils to reason about what causes what in a number sentence.

clusters.rationale: Commutativity is a distinct conceptual cluster that deepens understanding of the operation structure, building on table knowledge. Standalone as the domain has three well-separated concepts.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.OA.B.5 - Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide

clusters.cluster_name: Find and compare fractions of shapes and sets, including equivalent fractions

thinking_lenses.rationale: Finding fractions of shapes and sets is directly about proportional part-whole reasoning — a half is always the same proportion regardless of the size of the whole, which is why 2/4 = 1/2.

Equivalent fractions reveal a pattern: multiplying or dividing numerator and denominator by the same number preserves the proportion — pupils begin to see this regularity when they spot that 2/4 and 1/2 shade the same amount.

clusters.rationale: Recognising fractions of quantities and identifying the first equivalence (2/4 = 1/2) naturally co-occur — equivalence arises directly from partitioning work. Only two concepts; a single cluster is appropriate.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.G.A.3 - Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares

clusters.cluster_name: Measure accurately using standard units of length, mass, temperature and capacity

thinking_lenses.rationale: Standard units make measurement a quantitative comparison — pupils learn that 30 cm is three times 10 cm, and 500 g is half a kilogram, building proportional thinking about measurement scales.

clusters.rationale: Standard measurement is the foundation of the Measurement domain in Year 2. Standalone as a distinct pedagogical focus before time and money.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.MD.A - Measure and estimate lengths in standard units

clusters.cluster_name: Use £ and p notation to solve money problems

thinking_lenses.rationale: Money problems require pupils to reason with quantity in a real-world context — combining coins to make a total, giving change, and understanding that 100p = £1 all rest on proportional thinking about value.
Solving money word problems involves causal reasoning: spending a certain amount causes the remaining total to decrease by exactly that amount, making the additive and subtractive structure tangible.

clusters.rationale: Money is a distinct applied context requiring its own symbolic conventions and problem-solving strategies.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.MD.C.8 - Solve word problems involving dollar bills and coins

clusters.cluster_name: Tell and write the time to five minutes and use the language of time

thinking_lenses.rationale: Reading the clock to five-minute intervals draws directly on counting in 5s — the minute hand follows a predictable pattern around the 12 numbers, linking to the 5 times table the pupils are learning concurrently.
Five-minute intervals are a proportional partition of the hour — quarter past, half past and quarter to represent 1/4, 1/2 and 3/4 of 60 minutes, giving time-telling a proportional structure.

clusters.rationale: Time reading to five-minute intervals is a substantial standalone skill. C016 co-teaches with the times tables (counting in 5s underpins clock reading).
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.MD.C.7 - Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and describe properties of 2-D and 3-D shapes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Describing shapes by counting sides, vertices, faces and edges is the first systematic analysis of how structural properties define and distinguish shapes — the number and type of faces determines what a 3-D shape is called.

clusters.rationale: Properties of 2-D shapes (sides, symmetry) and 3-D shapes (faces, edges, vertices) are the foundational analytical skills for this domain. They provide the vocabulary for the connecting concept.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.G.A.1 - Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes

clusters.cluster_name: Explore the relationship between 2-D shapes and the faces of 3-D shapes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Identifying that the faces of a cube are squares or that a cylinder has circular faces shows pupils how a 3-D shape's structure is determined by its 2-D faces — the surface structure defines the solid.

clusters.rationale: Identifying 2-D shapes on the surface of 3-D shapes connects both property clusters and builds deeper spatial understanding. C019 explicitly co-teaches with both C017 and C018.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.G.A.1 - Recognize shapes by attributes

clusters.cluster_name: Describe and make movement using right angles and half, quarter and three-quarter turns

thinking_lenses.rationale: Half, quarter and three-quarter turns encode proportional fractions of a full rotation — pupils learn that a quarter turn is 1/4 of 360°, making this cluster a physical embodiment of proportional quantity.
The right angle is a structural unit of rotation: turns are described as one, two, three or four right angles, and understanding this unit connects the geometry of shape to the geometry of movement.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. The right angle as a standard unit of turn is the Year 2 position/direction focus and is taught as a standalone concept.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.G.A - Reason with shapes and their attributes

clusters.cluster_name: Interpret and construct pictograms, tally charts, block diagrams and tables

thinking_lenses.rationale: Constructing and reading pictograms, tally charts and block diagrams makes frequency patterns visible — pupils move from raw counts to representations that reveal which categories occur most and least often.
A correctly drawn chart is an evidence-based representation — pupils must ensure that every tally or block accurately encodes the data so that questions answered from it give reliable conclusions.

clusters.rationale: Constructing and reading representations is the foundational statistics skill; it must precede questioning and reasoning about data.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.MD.D.10 - Draw a picture graph and a bar graph to represent a data set

clusters.cluster_name: Ask and answer questions about data using addition and subtraction

thinking_lenses.rationale: Answering questions from a chart requires pupils to use the data as evidence — 'how many more chose X than Y?' demands reading the chart accurately and applying arithmetic to support a specific claim.

Asking and answering questions about data directs pupils to look for the most and least frequent categories — comparing tallies to find differences or totals starts the habit of noticing distributional patterns.

clusters.rationale: Asking and answering questions applies arithmetic to statistical contexts. C023 co-teaches with two-digit addition (MA-Y2-C005), confirming the cross-domain connection.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.MD.D.10 - Solve simple put-together, take-apart and compare problems using data

clusters.cluster_name: Extend counting sequences in multiples of 4, 8, 50 and 100

thinking_lenses.rationale: Each skip-count sequence has its own regular arithmetic pattern — multiples of 4 always increase by 4, multiples of 8 by 8, and the doubling link between 4s and 8s reveals a deeper multiplicative pattern across tables.

clusters.rationale: These four skip-counting sequences are linked by their co_teach_hints (C001, C003, C004 mutually co-teach) and collectively prepare pupils for the 3, 4 and 8 times tables. They establish the entry point for three-digit number work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.NBT.A.2 - Count within 1000, skip-count by 5s, 10s, and 100s

clusters.cluster_name: Understand and apply place value in three-digit numbers

thinking_lenses.rationale: Three-digit place value extends the same positional pattern: hundreds, tens and ones each follow the rule that each column is worth ten times its right-hand neighbour — partitioning C008 and finding 10/100 more or less (C005, C006) all exploit this consistent structure.
Understanding that 10 tens make one hundred, and that 100 is ten times 10, introduces the multiplicative scale factor that pupils must reason about when partitioning or adjusting three-digit numbers.

clusters.rationale: Place value understanding (C007), partitioning (C008), and finding 10/100 more or less (C005, C006) are tightly bound by co_teach_hints. Together they build the core conceptual architecture for three-digit numbers.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.NBT.A - Understand place value to hundreds

clusters.cluster_name: Compare, order and estimate numbers to 1000

thinking_lenses.rationale: Estimating and placing three-digit numbers on a number line requires pupils to judge relative magnitude — deciding that 650 is closer to 700 than to 600 involves proportional reasoning about position within an interval.
Comparing and ordering numbers to 1000 relies on the place value pattern: the hundreds digit is always compared first, then tens, then ones — the same left-to-right rule that applies at every scale.

clusters.rationale: Comparing/ordering, estimating, and reading/writing numbers in words all require a secure overall grasp of the size and representation of three-digit numbers. C010 co-teaches with C003 (scales link).
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.NBT.A.4 - Compare two three-digit numbers using >, =, < symbols

clusters.cluster_name: Add and subtract three-digit numbers mentally

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mental strategies for three-digit addition and subtraction rely on recognising patterns: partitioning into hundreds, tens and ones follows the same positional rule at every scale, so the same strategies apply.
Adding or subtracting a quantity causes a predictable change — mental methods make the causal structure explicit by tracking what happens to each place when numbers are combined or reduced.

clusters.rationale: Mental addition and subtraction with three-digit numbers are co-taught (C013 co-teaches with C012) and together establish fluency before formal methods are introduced.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.NBT.B.7 - Add and subtract within 1000 using concrete models or drawings

clusters.cluster_name: Add and subtract using formal columnar methods and check with estimation

thinking_lenses.rationale: The columnar algorithm is a systematic pattern applied digit-by-digit from right to left: the same exchange and borrowing rules repeat at every column, making formal written methods generalisable to any number size.

Using estimation and inverse operations to check results trains pupils to reason causally: if addition was applied correctly, subtracting one addend from the sum should return the other — a direct test of the operation's effect.

clusters.rationale: Columnar addition, columnar subtraction and the use of estimation and inverse operations to check belong together as the formal written methods cluster. C016 is explicitly about using estimation and inverses to validate results.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.NBT.B.7 - Add and subtract within 1000 using the standard algorithm

clusters.cluster_name: Recall the 3, 4 and 8 times tables and understand their connections

thinking_lenses.rationale: The four operations follow consistent patterns and rules (commutativity, distributivity, inverse relationships) that pupils recognise across different number types.
Each operation enacts a causal transformation: adding causes an increase, multiplying by a factor causes proportional growth — understanding this causality deepens fluency.

clusters.rationale: The 3, 4 and 8 times tables are the Year 3 statutory recall targets. C020 (doubling connection between 2, 4 and 8) is explicitly co-taught with C018 and C019. These four form a coherent knowledge cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.OA.C.7 - Fluently multiply and divide within 100

clusters.cluster_name: Multiply and solve scaling and correspondence problems

thinking_lenses.rationale: Scaling problems (e.g. 'three times as long') and correspondence problems (e.g. 'how many combinations?') are both fundamentally about multiplicative relationships between quantities — the core of proportional reasoning.
Written multiplication of a 2-digit number by a single digit extends the regular table patterns into multi-step computation, applying the same multiplicative structure to larger numbers.

clusters.rationale: Written multiplication (2-digit × 1-digit), scaling problems and correspondence problems all extend times table knowledge into applied contexts. C022 and C023 both co-teach with table concepts.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.OA.A.3 - Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems

clusters.cluster_name: Understand unit and non-unit fractions with small denominators

thinking_lenses.rationale: Unit fractions (1/b) establish the idea that a whole can be divided into b equal parts — this is the core proportional concept, and tenths explicitly bridge fractions to the decimal place value system.
The pattern that non-unit fractions are multiples of their unit fraction (3/5 is three 1/5s) is the structural insight that unifies this cluster and prepares pupils for fraction arithmetic.

clusters.rationale: Tenths (bridging fractions and place value), unit fractions and non-unit fractions together establish the conceptual foundation of the fraction number system in Year 3. All three mutually co-teach.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.NF.A.1 - Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts

clusters.cluster_name: Compare, order and add fractions with the same denominator

thinking_lenses.rationale: Comparing fractions with the same denominator requires reasoning about proportional size — 3/7 is less than 5/7 because the parts are equal in size and we have fewer of them.

Equivalent fractions introduce the key pattern that multiplying numerator and denominator by the same factor preserves value — pupils see this first through the regularity of fraction strips and number lines.

clusters.rationale: Equivalent fractions, adding/subtracting with the same denominator and comparing/ordering fractions are the procedural and relational skills built on the conceptual foundation. All three are mutually co-taught.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.NF.A.3 - Explain equivalence of fractions and compare fractions

clusters.cluster_name: Measure in mixed units and calculate perimeter

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mixed-unit measurement (m and cm, kg and g) develops pupils' understanding of the proportional relationship between units — 1 m = 100 cm encodes a scale factor of 100 that pupils must apply fluently.

Perimeter is determined by a shape's structural properties — the total length around the boundary is a direct consequence of the side lengths, making it an early application of structure-to-measurement reasoning.

clusters.rationale: Mixed-unit measurement and perimeter are both applied measurement skills that connect to number work and shape. They form the practical measurement cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.MD.B.4 - Measure lengths using rulers to the nearest half and quarter inch

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate with money and read the time accurately

thinking_lenses.rationale: Money calculations (adding totals, giving change) and time (24-hour clock, duration) both require reasoning with quantities on different scales — pounds/pence and hours/minutes each have fixed conversion ratios.

Roman numerals on clock faces introduce a different but regular number system, and the 24-hour clock follows a predictable pattern of adding 12 to pm times — pupils practise applying systematic rules to new notation.

clusters.rationale: Money calculations, Roman numerals on clock faces, 24-hour clock and duration of time are co-taught as a cluster (C032, C034, C035 mutually co-teach; C033 co-teaches with C035). Time and money together form the real-world applications cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.MD.A.1 - Tell and write time to the nearest minute and solve elapsed time problems

clusters.cluster_name: Draw 2-D shapes and make 3-D shapes using measurements and properties

thinking_lenses.rationale: Drawing shapes from given measurements requires pupils to understand how structural properties (specified side lengths, parallel lines) determine the resulting shape — the properties constrain what can be constructed.

clusters.rationale: Drawing/constructing shapes and identifying horizontal, vertical, perpendicular and parallel lines are both construction-oriented skills. C036 co-teaches with C039.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.G.A.1 - Understand that shapes in different categories may share attributes

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and compare angles including right angles

thinking_lenses.rationale: Angles are structural properties of shapes and turns — whether an angle is acute, right, or obtuse directly determines the shape's corner geometry and governs relationships between sides.
Comparing angles as greater or less than a right angle introduces ordinal quantity reasoning about rotation — pupils begin to see angle as a measurable quantity rather than just a visual feature.

clusters.rationale: The concept of an angle and the identification of right angles versus acute/obtuse are closely related. C039 links back to these via co_teach_hints.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.G.A.1 - Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles and perpendicular and parallel lines

clusters.cluster_name: Interpret and construct scaled bar charts and pictograms

thinking_lenses.rationale: Scaled charts introduce the idea that one symbol or bar can represent multiple items — recognising the scale pattern (each symbol = 5 items) and applying it consistently is the key cognitive demand.
Constructing a scaled chart requires pupils to make evidence-representation decisions: choosing an appropriate scale that accurately encodes the data without distortion.

clusters.rationale: Scaled charts are the Year 3 entry point for statistics, requiring pupils to understand one symbol/bar represents more than one item. Foundational representation skill.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.MD.B.3 - Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph

clusters.cluster_name: Solve one-step and two-step questions using information from data

thinking_lenses.rationale: Answering two-step questions from charts (e.g. 'how many more children preferred cats and dogs combined than fish?') requires pupils to extract evidence from the data and apply arithmetic to construct a supported answer.

Multi-step data questions direct pupils to notice comparative patterns across categories — which group is largest, by how much, and what does that tell us — building the reasoning habits of statistical literacy.

clusters.rationale: Moving from reading charts to reasoning from data and answering multi-step questions is the key statistical thinking progression in Year 3.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.MD.B.3 - Solve one- and two-step problems using information presented in charts

clusters.cluster_name: Understand place value and count in multiples with four-digit numbers

thinking_lenses.rationale: Four-digit place value applies the same positional rule as before, now extended to the thousands column — the regular base-10 pattern means pupils can immediately read and partition any four-digit number using the same framework.
Understanding that the thousands column represents quantities 1000 times larger than the ones column extends the proportional scaling insight of place value to a new magnitude.

clusters.rationale: Four-digit place value is the foundational concept; counting in multiples of 6, 7, 9, 25 and 1000 extends skip-counting to match the new times table demands. C002 co-teaches with C004.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 2.NBT.A - Understand place value

clusters.cluster_name: Round to the nearest 10, 100 and 1000 and use negative numbers in context

thinking_lenses.rationale: Rounding requires pupils to judge where a number sits proportionally within an interval — 3,748 rounded to the nearest 1000 involves deciding it is closer to 4,000 than to 3,000, which is a proportional judgement.
Negative numbers extend the familiar counting pattern below zero — the sequence ...-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3... follows the same regular step rule, just in both directions.

clusters.rationale: Rounding and negative numbers both extend the number line concept beyond the positive integers. C004 co-teaches with C002.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.NBT.A.1 - Use place value understanding to round whole numbers

clusters.cluster_name: Read Roman numerals to 100

thinking_lenses.rationale: Roman numerals follow a combinatorial pattern of additive and subtractive rules (IV = 4, IX = 9) — recognising these systematic rules is the cognitive work, offering a contrast with the positional pattern of Hindu-Arabic numerals.

clusters.rationale: Roman numerals is a discrete knowledge strand within NC Number that does not co-teach with other Year 4 number concepts. Standalone practice cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: UK NC Year 4 statutory requirement: Roman numerals to 100

clusters.cluster_name: Add and subtract four-digit numbers using formal columnar methods

thinking_lenses.rationale: Extending columnar methods to four-digit numbers applies the same column-by-column exchange pattern as before — pupils see that the algorithm scales automatically because place value follows regular rules.

Exchange (carrying/borrowing) is a causal chain: when a column exceeds 9 or falls below 0, it causes a change in the adjacent column — tracking this effect across multiple columns is the key procedural challenge.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. Four-digit columnar addition and subtraction (with exchange at multiple places) is the singular statutory focus and stands alone.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.NBT.B.4 - Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm

clusters.cluster_name: Recall all multiplication tables to 12 × 12 and use short multiplication

thinking_lenses.rationale: Completing all 12 times tables reveals rich cross-table patterns — the 6s are double the 3s, the 9s have a digit-sum pattern, the 12s extend the 6s — and short multiplication applies these patterns to larger numbers systematically.
Times table fluency underpins all multiplicative reasoning: knowing 7 × 8 = 56 means that 7 groups of 8 scale to 56 — a proportional relationship that pupils apply repeatedly in short multiplication.

clusters.rationale: Complete times table recall is the major Year 4 milestone; short multiplication applies it to 2- and 3-digit numbers. C007 co-teaches with C008.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.OA.C.7 - Fluently multiply and divide within 100

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate factor pairs and use commutativity in mental calculation

thinking_lenses.rationale: The four operations follow consistent patterns and rules (commutativity, distributivity, inverse relationships) that pupils recognise across different number types.
Each operation enacts a causal transformation: adding causes an increase, multiplying by a factor causes proportional growth — understanding this causality deepens fluency.

clusters.rationale: Factor pairs and commutativity are the conceptual tools that underpin flexible mental multiplication strategies — a distinct cluster from the recall/procedural focus.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.OA.B.4 - Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1-100

clusters.cluster_name: Understand hundredths and extend decimal place value

thinking_lenses.rationale: Hundredths extend the place value system below the decimal point — understanding that 0.01 is one hundredth of 1 requires the same proportional scaling insight (each place is 1/10 of the one to its left) applied in a new direction.

The decimal place value pattern (each column is 1/10 of the previous one) is the same rule that governs the whole-number columns, just extended rightward — recognising this consistent pattern is the key insight.

clusters.rationale: Hundredths and decimal place value and the decimal equivalents of common fractions are co-taught (C010 and C012 mutually co-teach) and together establish the decimal number system.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.NF.C - Understand decimal notation for fractions

clusters.cluster_name: Generate and use equivalent fractions

thinking_lenses.rationale: Generating equivalent fractions by multiplying numerator and denominator by the same factor is proportional reasoning in action — the ratio of part to whole stays constant even as the absolute numbers change.
The family of fractions equivalent to 1/2 (2/4, 3/6, 4/8...) follows a clear multiplicative pattern, giving pupils a systematic procedure they can apply to any fraction.

clusters.rationale: Generating equivalent fractions using multiples and factors is a distinct procedural skill that builds on Year 3 fraction understanding and underpins all fraction arithmetic to come.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.NF.A.1 - Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n×a)/(n×b)

clusters.cluster_name: Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting and measuring

thinking_lenses.rationale: Area is a structural property of 2-D shapes — the number of unit squares that cover a rectilinear shape is determined entirely by its dimensions, making this the first encounter with how shape structure determines measurable quantity.

Comparing areas of different rectilinear shapes requires reasoning about quantity — pupils must judge which region contains more square units and begin to see that doubling a side more than doubles the area.

clusters.rationale: Area is the new measurement concept introduced in Year 4 and provides the conceptual entry point for the domain.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 3.MD.C.5 - Recognise area as an attribute of plane figures

clusters.cluster_name: Convert between metric units of length, mass and volume

thinking_lenses.rationale: Metric conversion is proportional scaling: 1 km = 1000 m means every measurement in km is 1000 times larger when expressed in m, and pupils must apply this multiplicative scale factor reliably.

clusters.rationale: Metric conversion is a substantial and distinct procedural skill that applies place value understanding to measurement.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.MD.A.1 - Know relative sizes of measurement units

clusters.cluster_name: Classify triangles and quadrilaterals by their properties

thinking_lenses.rationale: Classifying triangles (equilateral, isosceles, scalene, right-angled) and quadrilaterals (square, rectangle, rhombus, parallelogram, trapezium) requires pupils to identify how specific structural properties — equal sides, equal angles, parallel sides — define each category.

clusters.rationale: Classification of triangles and quadrilaterals is the primary shape-properties focus in Year 4. Provides the vocabulary for symmetry work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.G.A.2 - Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and complete patterns with lines of symmetry

thinking_lenses.rationale: Lines of symmetry are a structural property that constrains what a shape can look like — completing a symmetric pattern requires pupils to understand that every point on one side has an exact mirror-image counterpart on the other.

Symmetry is itself a pattern — the regularity that each half is the mirror image of the other — and identifying how many lines of symmetry a shape has reveals deeper regularities in shape classification.

clusters.rationale: Lines of symmetry are a distinct geometric concept best taught after classification, linking to the classification properties of shapes (e.g. equilateral triangles have 3 lines).
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.G.A.3 - Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure

clusters.cluster_name: Describe and plot positions using coordinates in the first quadrant

thinking_lenses.rationale: The coordinate system is a structural framework where position is determined by two perpendicular number lines — understanding how x and y values jointly locate a point is the key structural insight.
Reading and plotting coordinates requires reasoning with exact quantities along each axis — the x-value and y-value each represent a precise distance from the origin on their respective scales.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. First-quadrant coordinate work is the complete Year 4 position/direction curriculum.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.G.A.1 - Use a pair of perpendicular number lines to define a coordinate system

clusters.cluster_name: Read, interpret and draw line graphs showing continuous data over time

thinking_lenses.rationale: Line graphs reveal temporal patterns in continuous data — whether a quantity is increasing, decreasing or staying stable over time, and whether the rate of change is constant or varying.
Reading a line graph to answer questions requires pupils to use the plotted line as evidence — interpolating between points and describing what the data shows involves making evidence-based claims.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. Time graphs (line graphs) introduce continuous data and are the Year 4 statistics focus, distinct from the discrete data work of Y2-Y3.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.MD.B.2 - Represent and interpret data

clusters.cluster_name: Read, write and order numbers to 1,000,000 and round to any power of 10

thinking_lenses.rationale: Extending place value to six digits applies the same positional pattern — each column is ten times its right-hand neighbour — demonstrating that the number system scales infinitely by the same repeating rule.

Rounding to any power of 10 requires proportional judgement about where a number sits within progressively larger intervals — rounding 374,521 to the nearest 100,000 demands comparing it proportionally to 300,000 and 400,000.

clusters.rationale: Six-digit place value and rounding to any power of 10 (nearest 10,000; 100,000) are the two statutory Year 5 number/PV requirements. Only two concepts; single cluster appropriate.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.NBT.A.1 - Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 10 times as much as what it represents in the place to its right

clusters.cluster_name: Add and subtract whole numbers with more than four digits using mental and written strategies

thinking_lenses.rationale: Extending addition and subtraction to five or more digits applies the same columnar algorithm pattern — the exchange rule is unchanged regardless of how many columns are involved.

Choosing between mental and written strategies requires pupils to reason about effect: large round numbers are easily adjusted mentally, while irregular large numbers are better handled with a formal written procedure.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. Extension of addition and subtraction to larger numbers is the Year 5 focus, consolidating formal columnar methods.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.NBT.B.7 - Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths

clusters.cluster_name: Understand factors, multiples, primes, squares and cubes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Prime numbers, factors, multiples, squares and cubes are all defined by recognising patterns in the multiplication structure of integers — pupils search for regularities (which numbers have exactly two factors? which grow as n²?) that reveal the architecture of number.

Prime factorisation reveals the multiplicative structure underlying every integer — understanding that any composite number can be expressed uniquely as a product of primes is a deep structural insight.

clusters.rationale: Prime/composite numbers and factors/multiples are mutually co-taught (C003 and C005 co-teach). Square and cube numbers naturally accompany this cluster as related number theory. Together they build multiplicative number sense before formal algorithms.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.B.4 - Find greatest common factor and least common multiple

clusters.cluster_name: Multiply and divide using formal written methods

thinking_lenses.rationale: Long multiplication and short division apply systematic patterns — each step in long multiplication follows the same partial-product logic, and short division applies the same remainder-carry pattern at every column.
Multiplying a 4-digit number by a 2-digit number and interpreting remainders in division both require pupils to reason about the proportional scale of the result relative to the inputs.

clusters.rationale: Long multiplication (4-digit × 2-digit) and short division with remainders are the two formal written method targets for Year 5. Both are high teaching-weight and procedurally distinct from the number theory cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.NBT.B.5 - Fluently multiply multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm

clusters.cluster_name: Convert between mixed numbers and improper fractions and add fractions with different denominators

thinking_lenses.rationale: Adding fractions with different denominators requires finding a common denominator — a process that depends on recognising that equivalent fractions represent the same proportion, regardless of how the numerator and denominator are scaled.

Converting between mixed numbers and improper fractions follows a systematic rule (multiply the whole part by the denominator, then add the numerator) — a regular pattern pupils can apply mechanically once understood.

clusters.rationale: Mixed numbers/improper fractions and adding with different denominators are the procedural fraction targets that build on Year 3-4 equivalence work. Together they represent the Year 5 fraction arithmetic cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.NF.A - Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions

clusters.cluster_name: Extend decimal place value to thousandths and understand percentages

thinking_lenses.rationale: Thousandths extend the decimal place value scale one step further, and percentages introduce a fixed-denominator proportional representation (parts per 100) — both are tools for expressing precise proportional quantities.

The same place value pattern (each column 1/10 of the one to its left) applies to thousandths, and percentage equivalences follow predictable patterns — 50% = 0.5 = 1/2 exemplifies a family of linked representations.

clusters.rationale: Decimal place value to three decimal places and the concept of percentage as parts per hundred are both representational knowledge concepts that expand the number system. Together they set up the fraction-decimal-percentage equivalence work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.NBT.A.3 - Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths

clusters.cluster_name: Understand and calculate the volume of cuboids

thinking_lenses.rationale: Volume is determined by the three-dimensional structure of the cuboid — length, width and height together determine how many unit cubes fill the space, making this the first encounter with how 3-D structure produces a scalar measurement.

The formula V = l × w × h encodes a multiplicative scaling relationship — doubling one dimension doubles the volume, but doubling all three dimensions multiplies volume by eight, making proportional reasoning about scale essential.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. Volume of cuboids (V = l × w × h) is the new measurement concept introduced in Year 5.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.MD.C.3 - Recognise volume as an attribute of solid figures

clusters.cluster_name: Measure angles with a protractor and apply angle facts

thinking_lenses.rationale: The three angle facts (angles on a straight line = 180°, at a point = 360°, in a triangle = 180°) express structural constraints — knowing some angles in a configuration determines the remaining ones because of these fixed relationships.
Measuring angles in degrees introduces rotation as a precisely quantifiable property, and the 360° full turn provides the proportional reference — a right angle is exactly 1/4 of a full turn.

clusters.rationale: Measuring angles in degrees and applying the three key angle facts (straight line = 180°, point = 360°, triangle = 180°) are taught together as a coherent angles cluster. Both use degrees and build directly on each other.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 4.MD.C.5 - Recognise angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint

clusters.cluster_name: Reflect and translate shapes in all four quadrants of a coordinate grid

thinking_lenses.rationale: Reflections and translations preserve the shape's structural properties (side lengths, angles) while changing its position — understanding which properties are invariant under each transformation is the key structural insight.
Describing a translation as 'move 3 right and 2 up' reveals a pattern: each vertex moves by the same vector, so the transformation is completely regular and predictable from a single rule.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. Reflections and translations in all four quadrants extend Year 4 first-quadrant coordinate work to the full Cartesian plane.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.G.A.2 - Represent real world and mathematical problems by graphing points in the first quadrant

clusters.cluster_name: Read and interpret graphs, tables and timetables to solve comparison problems

thinking_lenses.rationale: Using timetables and data tables to answer comparison problems requires pupils to extract the relevant evidence, apply it carefully, and draw only the conclusions the data warrants.

Interpreting diverse data representations — line graphs, tables, timetables — requires noticing patterns like trends over time, peak values or repeated intervals that allow pupils to answer questions efficiently.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. Year 5 statistics focuses on interpretation and reasoning across a variety of data representations including timetables.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.MD.B.2 - Make a line plot to display a data set and solve problems

clusters.cluster_name: Read, write and order whole numbers to 10,000,000

thinking_lenses.rationale: Seven-digit numbers apply the same positional pattern — the millions column is ten times the hundred-thousands column — showing pupils that the same base-10 rule scales infinitely.

Reading and ordering numbers up to ten million requires pupils to reason about magnitude at a very large scale — comparing 3,750,000 to 4,200,000 demands understanding of the proportional distance between them.

clusters.rationale: Seven-digit place value is the Year 6 extension of place value and is the entry point for the domain before rounding and negative numbers.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.NBT.A.1 - Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit represents 10 times what it represents in the place to its right

clusters.cluster_name: Round to any degree of accuracy and calculate intervals across zero

thinking_lenses.rationale: Rounding to any degree of accuracy and calculating intervals across zero both require proportional judgement — how large is the gap between -4 and 3, and where does 2,345,678 sit when rounded to the nearest million?

The pattern of negative-to-positive number lines is the same arithmetic structure extended through zero — intervals across zero follow the same additive logic as positive intervals, just spanning the axis.

clusters.rationale: Rounding to any degree of accuracy and negative numbers/intervals across zero are co-taught (C002 co-teaches with C003) and together complete the Year 6 number system coverage.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.C.6 - Understand a rational number as a point on the number line

MA-Y6-D002.domain_name: Number - Addition, Subtraction, Multiplication and Division

clusters.cluster_name: Multiply and divide using formal long methods

thinking_lenses.rationale: The four operations follow consistent patterns and rules (commutativity, distributivity, inverse relationships) that pupils recognise across different number types.
Each operation enacts a causal transformation: adding causes an increase, multiplying by a factor causes proportional growth — understanding this causality deepens fluency.

clusters.rationale: Long multiplication and long division are the two formal written method pinnacles of primary arithmetic. They represent the major Year 6 procedural target.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.B.2 - Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm

clusters.cluster_name: Apply order of operations and work with common factors, multiples and primes

thinking_lenses.rationale: BIDMAS is a fixed pattern of precedence rules for evaluating expressions — recognising that this rule applies consistently regardless of the numbers involved is the key insight, just as factor/multiple relationships follow the multiplication table patterns.

Order of operations determines which calculation is performed first, causing a specific intermediate result that affects the final answer — changing the order of operations changes the result, making this a precise causal reasoning challenge.

clusters.rationale: Order of operations (BIDMAS) and common factors/multiples/primes are the conceptual number theory targets of Year 6. C006 co-teaches with C029.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.B.4 - Find GCF and LCM; use distributive property

clusters.cluster_name: Develop mathematical fluency and apply problem-solving strategies

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mathematical fluency depends on recognising structural patterns quickly — efficient problem-solving means spotting that a problem fits a known pattern and selecting the appropriate strategy, rather than calculating from scratch.

Problem-solving in Year 6 requires pupils to construct and justify mathematical arguments — selecting a strategy, showing working and explaining why an answer is correct are all forms of evidence-based reasoning.

clusters.rationale: Mathematical fluency with number and problem-solving strategies are cross-cutting process skills that permeate Year 6 mathematics. C029 is linked to C006; C031 represents the statutory problem-solving requirement.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.MP - Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them

clusters.cluster_name: Simplify, compare and add fractions with different denominators

thinking_lenses.rationale: Simplifying fractions and adding with unlike denominators both require proportional reasoning — simplification preserves the ratio of part to whole, and finding a common denominator creates proportionally equivalent representations of each fraction.

The pattern of fraction simplification (divide by HCF) and the algorithm for adding fractions with unlike denominators (find LCM of denominators) are systematic rules that pupils apply reliably once the underlying proportional pattern is understood.

clusters.rationale: Simplifying/comparing fractions and adding/subtracting with different denominators are co-taught (C008 lists C009 in co_teach_hints). Together they consolidate fraction arithmetic.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 5.NF.A.1 - Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators

clusters.cluster_name: Multiply and divide fractions and convert fluently between fractions, decimals and percentages

thinking_lenses.rationale: Fraction-decimal-percentage equivalence is fundamentally about representing the same proportion in three different notations — fluent conversion relies on understanding that 3/4, 0.75 and 75% all describe the same part-whole relationship.

Multiplying fractions follows a clean pattern (multiply numerators, multiply denominators) and dividing by a fraction follows the keep-change-flip pattern — these regular algorithmic rules are the operational backbone of the cluster.

clusters.rationale: Fraction multiplication/division and fraction-decimal-percentage equivalences are the upper primary fraction targets. C011 co-teaches with C008.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.A.1 - Interpret and compute quotients of fractions

clusters.cluster_name: Understand and use ratio and proportion to solve problems

thinking_lenses.rationale: Ratio and proportion are the formal language of multiplicative comparison — this cluster teaches pupils to express and use relative quantities directly, bridging all prior fraction and multiplicative work to KS3 Ratio, Proportion and Rates of Change.

clusters.rationale: Only one concept in this domain. Ratio and proportion is the new Year 6 domain that bridges to KS3 Ratio, Proportion and Rates of Change.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.RP.A - Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems

clusters.cluster_name: Use algebraic notation and formulae with letters for unknowns

thinking_lenses.rationale: Algebraic notation at Year 6 is the formal language for expressing numerical patterns with letters — writing 'n + 2' to describe a sequence generalises the repeated +2 pattern to any starting value.
Formulae express causal relationships: substituting a value for the letter causes a specific output — understanding this input-output structure is the gateway to algebraic reasoning at KS3.

clusters.rationale: Algebraic notation and formulae is the gateway concept for Year 6 algebra, introducing the idea of using letters to represent unknowns. Must precede sequence and equation work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.EE.A.2 - Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers

clusters.cluster_name: Generate and describe linear sequences and solve equations in two variables

thinking_lenses.rationale: Generating and describing linear sequences requires pupils to express the rule algebraically — finding the nth term formula formalises the arithmetic pattern so it can be applied to any position.
Two-variable equations (y = x + 3, etc.) express how changing x causes a predictable change in y — this is the earliest encounter with functional relationships, laying groundwork for KS3 graph work.

clusters.rationale: Linear sequences, two-variable equations and mathematical reasoning/justification are co-taught (C014 and C030 mutually co-teach). Together they represent the Year 6 algebra application and reasoning cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.EE.C.9 - Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate area and volume using formulae for 2-D and 3-D shapes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Area of triangles (½ × base × height) and parallelograms (base × height), and volume of cubes and cuboids, are all determined by the shape's structural dimensions — the formula encodes how the geometry produces the measurable quantity.

The area and volume formulae encode proportional scaling relationships: area scales as the square of linear dimensions and volume as the cube, so reasoning about how changes in size affect the measurements is central to the cluster.

clusters.rationale: Area of triangles and parallelograms and volume of cubes/cuboids are co-taught (C016 co-teaches with C015). Both apply the same principle of formula-based measurement and naturally belong together.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.G.A - Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume

clusters.cluster_name: Know and apply angle facts in polygons and circles

thinking_lenses.rationale: Angle facts in polygons (sum of interior angles = (n-2) × 180°) and the parts of a circle (radius, diameter, circumference) are structural properties — the number of sides determines the interior angle sum, and the relationship between radius and diameter is fixed.

clusters.rationale: Angle facts in polygons and the parts of a circle are co-taught (C018 co-teaches with C017). They establish the shape-property knowledge before problem-solving application.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.G.B.5 - Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles

clusters.cluster_name: Identify properties of 3-D shapes and apply angle reasoning to solve problems

thinking_lenses.rationale: Drawing nets and identifying 3-D shape properties requires pupils to reason about how a flat structure folds into a solid — the structural relationships between faces, edges and vertices determine the shape's 3-D form.

Applying angle facts to find missing angles in multi-step problems requires constructing a chain of deductive reasoning — each step uses a known fact as evidence to derive the next angle, building a mathematical argument.

clusters.rationale: 3-D shape properties/nets and applying angle facts to solve multi-step problems are co-taught with the angle-facts concept and represent the application tier of the domain.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.G.A.4 - Represent three-dimensional figures using nets

clusters.cluster_name: Plot and describe coordinates in all four quadrants

thinking_lenses.rationale: Extending coordinates to all four quadrants reveals the structural symmetry of the Cartesian plane — negative x-values mirror positive ones, and the four quadrants have a regular structural relationship that pupils can exploit.
The sign pattern of coordinates in each quadrant (+,+), (-,+), (-,-), (+,-) follows a regular rule that pupils can learn and use to identify quadrants without counting from the origin.

clusters.rationale: Four-quadrant coordinates extend Year 5 work and provide the spatial framework needed before transformations on the grid.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.C.6 - Understand a rational number as a point on the number line; extend to the coordinate plane

clusters.cluster_name: Perform and describe translations and reflections on a coordinate grid

thinking_lenses.rationale: Translating and reflecting shapes on a coordinate grid demonstrates that these transformations preserve the structural properties of the shape while systematically changing all coordinates — the transformation is described by a rule that applies equally to every vertex.

A translation by (+3, -2) shifts every point by the same vector — a completely regular pattern — and reflection in y = x swaps the x and y coordinates of every point, revealing a systematic relational pattern.

clusters.rationale: Translations and reflections on the full four-quadrant grid apply coordinate knowledge to geometric transformation, building on Year 5's work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.G.A.3 - Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations and reflections on two-dimensional figures

clusters.cluster_name: Construct and interpret pie charts and other statistical representations

thinking_lenses.rationale: Pie charts represent data as proportional sectors — constructing one requires calculating what fraction of 360° each category corresponds to, making this the most explicitly proportional statistical representation.

Interpreting pie charts involves reading proportional evidence — 'roughly a quarter of the pie is red, so about 25% chose red' — and comparing sectors requires judging relative proportions rather than absolute counts.

clusters.rationale: Pie charts (reading and calculating proportional sectors) and the broader skill of constructing/interpreting statistical charts are co-taught (C028 co-teaches with C020). Together they cover the representational strand.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.SP.B.4 - Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate and interpret averages including mean, median and mode

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mean, median and mode each summarise the data differently — choosing which best represents a dataset, and interpreting what a calculated average tells us about the whole distribution, are evidence-based reasoning tasks.

The mean is a redistributive pattern — it represents what each value would be if the total were shared equally — and the median finds the central position in an ordered sequence, revealing distributional structure.

clusters.rationale: Mean and the mode/median pair are co-taught (C021 and C027 mutually co-teach) and together provide a complete picture of central tendency at Year 6 level.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.SP.B.5 - Summarise numerical data sets in relation to their context

clusters.cluster_name: Describe and compare data distributions and use probability language

thinking_lenses.rationale: Comparing two distributions requires constructing an evidence-based argument using averages and range — 'Group A performed better on average, but Group B was more consistent' is a statistical claim that must be justified from the data.

Probability language (certain, likely, unlikely, impossible) and early probability as a fraction both require proportional reasoning — expressing likelihood as a number between 0 and 1 connects distributional description to the probability scale.

clusters.rationale: Describing distributions and introducing probability both require understanding likelihood and variation. Both co-teach with the averages cluster (C026 lists C020, C021, C027, C028; C025 is referenced by the averages cluster). Placed here as the analytical reasoning capstone.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.SP.C.5 - Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1

clusters.cluster_name: Develop and sustain mathematical fluency across number and calculation

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mathematical fluency is grounded in recognising structural patterns that make calculation efficient — knowing the index laws, fraction rules and operation properties as reliable patterns that apply consistently across number types.
Knowing when to use a calculator versus mental or written methods requires reasoning about which approach causes the most efficient and reliable result for a given calculation type.

clusters.rationale: Mathematical fluency (rapid recall and accurate application) and appropriate calculator use are complementary strands of the same domain: knowing when and how to compute efficiently.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.MP.6 - Attend to precision

clusters.cluster_name: Construct and communicate formal mathematical arguments and proofs

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mathematical proof is the highest form of evidence-based argument — pupils must construct a deductive chain where each step follows necessarily from the previous, with no gaps, using axioms and established results as evidence.

Many proofs involve identifying an underlying algebraic or geometric pattern and showing it holds in general — the cluster includes proof by counter-example, algebraic proof and geometric reasoning, all of which begin by recognising a structural pattern.

clusters.rationale: Mathematical reasoning, formal argument and geometric proof are a coherent cluster. C095 co-teaches with C075 and C089. Geometric proof is an application of formal argument in a specific domain.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSG-CO.C.9 - Prove theorems about lines and angles

clusters.cluster_name: Apply problem-solving strategies, mathematical modelling and multiple representations

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mathematical modelling is the process of building a simplified model of a real-world situation — pupils must decide which features to include, which to ignore, and how to represent the system mathematically.

Moving between representations (graphical, algebraic, numerical, diagrammatic) requires pupils to verify that each form encodes the same mathematical structure — a form of evidence-based checking that the model is consistent.

clusters.rationale: Problem-solving strategies, moving between representations and mathematical modelling are the three interlocking process skills in this domain. All three are process concepts that pervade KS3.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math MP.1-4 - Make sense of problems, reason abstractly, construct arguments, model with mathematics

clusters.cluster_name: Understand place value, negative numbers and order real numbers

thinking_lenses.rationale: Ordering real numbers including decimals, negatives and integers requires applying the consistent positional pattern of the number line — the same left-to-right magnitude rule governs all real numbers, regardless of type.

Inequality notation and ordering real numbers across the number line are fundamentally about reasoning with quantity and magnitude — placing -3.7 relative to -4 and -3 requires proportional judgement.

clusters.rationale: Place value with decimals, negative integers, ordering real numbers and inequality symbols all co-teach together (C001, C003, C004 mutually link; C003 co-teaches with C002 and C004). These form the foundational number system cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.C.6 - Understand a rational number as a point on the number line; apply to all four quadrants

clusters.cluster_name: Apply prime factorisation, HCF, LCM and index notation

thinking_lenses.rationale: Prime factorisation reveals the multiplicative building blocks of every integer — the fundamental theorem of arithmetic states every integer has a unique prime factorisation, which is a deep pattern underlying the entire number system.

Index notation encodes repeated multiplication compactly — understanding that a³ means a × a × a and applying index laws requires grasping how the structure of the notation determines the operation being described.

clusters.rationale: Prime numbers, factors/multiples, HCF/LCM, prime factorisation and index notation are tightly linked by co_teach_hints (C006, C007, C008 mutually co-teach; C008 and C014 co-teach). This is the number theory cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.NS.B.4 - Find GCF and LCM of two whole numbers

clusters.cluster_name: Perform operations with fractions, negative numbers and use order of operations

thinking_lenses.rationale: Operations with fractions, negative numbers and BIDMAS all follow consistent algebraic rules (e.g. multiplying two negatives gives a positive; dividing by a fraction inverts it) — the cognitive work is recognising which pattern applies and applying it correctly.

Each arithmetic operation on a rational number causes a precise, predictable change — adding a negative causes a decrease, and applying BIDMAS in the wrong order causes a different result, making causal reasoning central to this cluster.

clusters.rationale: Operations with fractions, negative number arithmetic, BIDMAS and inverse operations all co-teach together (C009 lists C010, C012; C012 lists C009, C010, C011). These constitute the calculation fluency cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.NS.A - Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers

clusters.cluster_name: Use powers, roots, standard form and understand surds

thinking_lenses.rationale: Powers and their inverses follow elegant patterns (index laws) that pupils can identify and apply systematically across all number representations.
Standard form and significant figures are tools for reasoning about scale — expressing very large or very small quantities in ways that preserve their proportional relationships.

clusters.rationale: Powers and roots, exact vs approximate roots and standard form are linked (C013 lists C014, C019; C016 links to C014). These represent the advanced number representation cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.EE.A.1 - Know and apply the properties of integer exponents

clusters.cluster_name: Work with percentages, fractions as operators and apply to real contexts

thinking_lenses.rationale: Percentages and fractions as operators both express multiplicative scaling of a quantity — 'find 35% of 240' means scale 240 by the proportion 35/100, making proportional reasoning the core cognitive demand throughout this cluster.

Applying a percentage increase or decrease causes a predictable effect on the original amount — using a multiplier (e.g. 1.15 for a 15% increase) encodes the causal relationship between rate and outcome compactly.

clusters.rationale: Decimal-fraction equivalence, the percentage concept, percentage calculations and fractions/percentages as operators are all linked (C020 lists C018, C019, C009, C012). This is the percentage and proportional representation cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.RP.A.3 - Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step percent problems

clusters.cluster_name: Round to significant figures and understand error intervals

thinking_lenses.rationale: Significant figures preserve proportional precision — 3 s.f. means the same relative accuracy whether a number is 0.00347 or 34,700, making this a scale-invariant proportional tool.

Error intervals express the bounds within which a rounded measurement must lie — pupils must reason from the precision of a measurement to the range of possible true values, which is an argument about what the evidence does and cannot tell us.

clusters.rationale: Rounding/approximation, error intervals and the nature of infinite number sets are grouped as the estimation and number sets cluster. C022 uses inequality notation (linking to C004); C024 connects to the nature of rational number sets.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.NS.A.2 - Use rational approximations of irrational numbers

clusters.cluster_name: Understand algebraic notation and vocabulary

thinking_lenses.rationale: Algebraic notation is a system for expressing generalised patterns — a letter represents any number that fits the relationship, so pupils are learning to read and write the language of pattern rather than specific numerical instances.

Understanding the distinction between an expression (a pattern) and an equation (a causal constraint) is the key conceptual split in this cluster — an equation asserts that a specific cause (a value of the variable) produces a specific effect (a result).

clusters.rationale: Algebraic notation conventions and algebraic vocabulary (expression, equation, term, coefficient, etc.) are the entry-point knowledge cluster for the whole Algebra domain.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.EE.A.2 - Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers

clusters.cluster_name: Simplify, expand and factorise algebraic expressions

thinking_lenses.rationale: Algebraic manipulation depends on recognising that equivalent forms follow structural patterns — collecting like terms, the distributive law for expanding brackets, and factorisation all apply consistently regardless of the specific coefficients.

Factorised form reveals the structural building blocks of an expression — (x + 2)(x + 3) shows the two linear factors that combine to produce x² + 5x + 6, making the structure of the quadratic transparent.

clusters.rationale: Collecting like terms, expanding single brackets, factorising and expanding binomial products form a coherent manipulation cluster. C029 co-teaches with C028, C030, C031; C031 co-teaches with C029.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSA-APR.A.1 - Perform arithmetic operations on polynomials

clusters.cluster_name: Substitute into expressions, form equations and change the subject of formulae

thinking_lenses.rationale: Solving equations is explicitly causal — each inverse operation applied to one side causes a corresponding change on the other, and pupils must track this causal chain until the variable is isolated.

Changing the subject of a formula applies the same sequence of inverse operations regardless of the formula's specific structure — recognising this generalised pattern is what allows pupils to rearrange any formula fluently.

clusters.rationale: Substitution, formula use, rearranging formulae, forming expressions and solving linear equations are all procedural algebra skills linked via co_teach_hints (C026 lists C034, C032; C034 co-teaches with C040). Together they form the equations and formulae cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.EE.B - Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities

clusters.cluster_name: Understand and draw linear and quadratic graphs using y = mx + c

thinking_lenses.rationale: Linear graphs are visual patterns — y = mx + c always produces a straight line because the constant gradient m means equal x-steps always produce equal y-steps, and the six concepts in this cluster (C036–C041) all describe facets of this regular linear pattern.
The gradient of a linear graph encodes the causal rate — increasing x by 1 causes y to increase by m — and graphical solutions to simultaneous equations show where two causal constraints intersect.

clusters.rationale: Four-quadrant coordinates, linear graphs, quadratic graphs, y=mx+c, gradient/intercept and graphical solutions are extensively cross-referenced by co_teach_hints (C039 lists C036, C037, C038, C040, C041). This is the graphs cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.F.B.4 - Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities

clusters.cluster_name: Solve simultaneous equations graphically and interpret non-linear graphs

thinking_lenses.rationale: Non-linear graphs (exponential, reciprocal, piecewise) each have characteristic shapes that are recognisable patterns — knowing that y = x² always produces a symmetric parabola and y = 1/x always produces a hyperbola is pattern recognition applied to function families.

Solving simultaneous equations graphically shows where two equations produce the same (x, y) pair — the intersection represents the unique causal conditions that satisfy both constraints simultaneously.

clusters.rationale: Simultaneous equations graphically and non-linear graphs (exponential, reciprocal, piecewise) are the advanced graph interpretation cluster at KS3, requiring all prior graph skills.
