clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.EE.C.8 - Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations

clusters.cluster_name: Generate, describe and find the nth term of arithmetic and geometric sequences

thinking_lenses.rationale: Sequences are the paradigmatic mathematical pattern — pupils identify the common difference or common ratio, express it algebraically as an nth term formula, and use it to predict any term.

Geometric sequences grow by a constant multiplicative ratio — understanding that each term is the previous term scaled by the same factor introduces exponential growth as a proportional quantity relationship.

clusters.rationale: Sequence generation, arithmetic sequences (nth term) and geometric sequences (common ratio) form a coherent sequences cluster. C044 co-teaches with C045, C046; C046 co-teaches with C045.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSF-IF.A.3 - Recognize that sequences are functions whose domain is a subset of the integers

MA-KS3-D006.domain_name: Ratio, Proportion and Rates of Change

clusters.cluster_name: Understand ratio notation, divide in a ratio and link to fractions

thinking_lenses.rationale: Ratio notation formalises proportional relationships — dividing a quantity in a given ratio requires pupils to find what fraction of the total each part represents, directly connecting ratio to fraction as representations of the same proportional idea.

Equivalent ratios follow the same pattern as equivalent fractions — multiplying or dividing all parts by the same factor preserves the ratio — and pupils use this regularity to simplify and scale ratios.

clusters.rationale: Ratio notation, dividing in a ratio, expressing as a fraction and the link between ratios and fractions are mutually co-taught (C050 lists C049, C051; C049 lists C050, C052, C053). This cluster establishes the conceptual foundation.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.RP.A.1 - Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language

clusters.cluster_name: Apply scale factors, percentage change and financial mathematics

thinking_lenses.rationale: Scale factors, percentage change and financial mathematics are all applied proportional reasoning — a scale factor of 2.5 enlarges every measurement by the same multiplier, and percentage change applies a proportional rate to a base quantity.

Percentage change problems encode causal relationships: a 20% increase causes the new value to be 1.2 times the original — understanding this causal multiplier structure underpins both simple and compound interest calculations.

clusters.rationale: Scale factors/diagrams, percentage change and financial mathematics are applied ratio and proportion contexts. C048 co-teaches with C053, C057; C054 is standalone with high practical relevance alongside financial contexts.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.RP.A.3 - Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step problems including percent

clusters.cluster_name: Solve problems involving direct and inverse proportion and multiplicative reasoning

thinking_lenses.rationale: Direct proportion (y = kx) and inverse proportion (y = k/x) are the two fundamental multiplicative relationships between quantities — recognising which applies and finding the constant of proportionality is the core skill of this cluster.

In direct proportion, increasing one variable causes a proportional increase in the other; in inverse proportion, increasing one variable causes a proportional decrease — the contrast in causal direction is the key conceptual distinction pupils must grasp.

clusters.rationale: Multiplicative relationships, direct proportion, inverse proportion and additive vs multiplicative reasoning are linked (C056 co-teaches with C055, C052, C094; C094 lists C055, C056). This is the proportional reasoning cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.RP.A.2 - Recognise and represent proportional relationships between quantities

clusters.cluster_name: Convert between units and use compound units in problem-solving

thinking_lenses.rationale: Unit conversion is proportional scaling — 1 mile = 1.6 km means every distance in miles scales by 1.6 to give kilometres — and compound units like speed (km/h) or density (g/cm³) are ratios of two quantities that together define a proportional rate.

Compound units encode relationships between physical quantities in a system — speed = distance ÷ time creates a model linking three quantities, and changing one while holding another constant reveals the systematic dependencies.

clusters.rationale: Unit conversion and compound units (speed, density, pressure) are co-taught (C047 co-teaches with C057; C057 extensively cross-references). These form the measurement application within the ratio domain.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.RP.A.3d - Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units

clusters.cluster_name: Derive and apply area and volume formulae for 2-D and 3-D shapes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Deriving area formulae for triangles, parallelograms and trapezia requires pupils to see how the structural dimensions (base, height, parallel sides) determine the measurement — the formula captures exactly how structure produces quantity.

Area and volume formulae encode proportional scaling laws — area scales as the square of linear dimensions and volume as the cube — so reasoning about how changes in size affect measurements is central to applying these formulae.

clusters.rationale: Area formulae (triangles, parallelograms, trapezia), volume of prisms and circle measurements are linked (C058 co-teaches with C059, C068, C072). These constitute the mensuration cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.G.A - Solve real-world problems involving area, surface area, and volume

clusters.cluster_name: Use geometric notation, drawing and construction tools accurately

thinking_lenses.rationale: Geometric constructions with compass and straight-edge produce exact figures whose structural properties (equal lengths, bisected angles, perpendicular lines) are guaranteed by the construction method — the tool use enforces the structural relationships.

clusters.rationale: Measuring/drawing, geometric constructions, notation and triangle labelling conventions all form the practical geometry toolkit. C063 co-teaches with C062, C064.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.G.A.2 - Draw geometric shapes with given conditions

clusters.cluster_name: Understand angle properties and apply to triangles, polygons and parallel lines

thinking_lenses.rationale: Angle properties (angles on a straight line, at a point, in parallel lines, in triangles and polygons) are structural constraints — each rule specifies how the angle relationships in a configuration are determined by its geometric structure.

Applying angle facts to find unknown angles requires constructing a deductive argument — each step cites a named property as evidence, and the chain of reasoning from known to unknown angles is a formal geometric proof.

clusters.rationale: Angle properties at a point, parallel line angles, triangle angle sum and polygon angle sum are tightly linked (C071 and C072 mutually co-teach; C073 co-teaches with C071, C072). This is the angle reasoning cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.G.A.5 - Use informal arguments to establish facts about angle sums and exterior angles

clusters.cluster_name: Prove and apply congruence and similarity in triangles

thinking_lenses.rationale: Congruence criteria (SSS, SAS, ASA, RHS) specify the minimal structural information needed to uniquely determine a triangle — proving congruence means showing that the given properties fully determine the shape.

Similarity is a proportional relationship — all corresponding sides of similar triangles are in the same ratio, making the entire cluster about identifying and using proportional scaling between congruent angle structures.

clusters.rationale: Congruence criteria, shape properties, congruent triangle construction and similarity/enlargement are extensively co-taught (C065 lists C064, C068, C071-076; C068 is linked to most geometry concepts). This is the shape reasoning cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.G.A.2 - Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if the second can be obtained from the first

clusters.cluster_name: Apply Pythagoras' Theorem and trigonometric ratios to right-angled triangles

thinking_lenses.rationale: Pythagoras' theorem and trigonometric ratios are structural properties of right-angled triangles — knowing two measurements determines the rest because the right angle constrains the relationship between all sides and angles.

Trigonometric ratios (sin, cos, tan) are proportional relationships — sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse is a ratio that is constant for a given angle regardless of the triangle's size, making this a deep application of proportional reasoning.

clusters.rationale: Pythagoras' Theorem and trigonometric ratios (sin, cos, tan) are the two capstone right-triangle concepts in KS3, both with high teaching weight (5). They are mutually co-referenced.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.G.B.7 - Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths

clusters.cluster_name: Identify, describe and perform geometric transformations

thinking_lenses.rationale: Each transformation (translation, rotation, reflection, enlargement) preserves or changes specific structural properties — understanding which properties are invariant (e.g. angles under enlargement, distances under rotation) defines the transformation's nature.

Enlargement is explicitly a proportional transformation — a scale factor of 3 triples every length while angles remain unchanged, making this a direct application of proportional reasoning to spatial change.

clusters.rationale: Transformations (translation, rotation, reflection) and 3-D shape properties are grouped here as the spatial reasoning application cluster, both requiring prior shape knowledge.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.G.A.1 - Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections and translations

clusters.cluster_name: Understand and calculate theoretical and experimental probability

thinking_lenses.rationale: Probability is grounded in recognising patterns across repeated trials and understanding how theoretical regularity emerges from random events.
The probability scale (0 to 1) and expressing likelihood as a fraction or decimal requires proportional reasoning about quantity.

clusters.rationale: Probability experiments, the probability scale summing to 1 and theoretical probability (sample spaces) are co-taught (C078 co-teaches with C081). These establish the foundational probability framework.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.SP.C.5 - Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1

clusters.cluster_name: Enumerate outcomes systematically using tables, grids and Venn diagrams

thinking_lenses.rationale: Probability is grounded in recognising patterns across repeated trials and understanding how theoretical regularity emerges from random events.
The probability scale (0 to 1) and expressing likelihood as a fraction or decimal requires proportional reasoning about quantity.

clusters.rationale: Systematic enumeration (sample space diagrams, Venn diagrams) is the key combinatorial skill that distinguishes KS3 probability from primary-level language work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.SP.C.8 - Find probabilities of compound events using organised lists, tables, tree diagrams and simulation

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate and interpret measures of central tendency and spread

thinking_lenses.rationale: Mean, median, mode and range are summary statistics that reveal the central pattern in a data set — pupils must recognise when values cluster around a centre and identify how outliers distort measures like the mean relative to the median.

Choosing which average best represents a data set is an argumentative act: pupils must justify their choice using properties of the distribution and acknowledge when a measure is misleading, building the habit of evidence-based statistical reasoning.

clusters.rationale: Mean, mode, median and range (with outliers) are tightly co-taught (C084 lists C083). These foundational summary statistics must be established before data representation work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.SP.B.5 - Summarise numerical data sets in relation to their context

clusters.cluster_name: Represent and compare data distributions using appropriate charts

thinking_lenses.rationale: Choosing an appropriate chart type (bar chart, pie chart, frequency polygon, cumulative frequency) depends on identifying the pattern in the data structure — whether it is categorical, continuous, grouped or cumulative — and selecting the representation that reveals that pattern most clearly.

Comparing two data distributions requires constructing a reasoned argument using statistical evidence — pupils must cite specific features (median, IQR, shape) from box plots or cumulative frequency curves to support claims about which group performed better or more consistently.

clusters.rationale: Data distribution, data representation (bar charts, pie charts, pictograms) and grouped data are co-taught (C085 lists C082, C083, C086; C084 lists C082, C083, C086). This is the data representation and analysis cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.SP.B.4 - Display numerical data in plots on a number line

clusters.cluster_name: Describe relationships between two variables using scatter graphs

thinking_lenses.rationale: Correlation is a bivariate pattern — pupils must identify whether the relationship between two variables is positive, negative or zero, and assess how strongly the points cluster around a line of best fit to characterise the strength of that pattern.

Drawing a line of best fit and using it to interpolate or extrapolate are evidence-based claims that require pupils to distinguish correlation from causation and acknowledge the limits of their model — a central habit of statistical argumentation.

clusters.rationale: Bivariate data and scatter graphs represent a distinct statistical idea (correlation between two variables) that is meaningfully different from univariate distribution work.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.SP.A.1 - Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data

clusters.cluster_name: Apply the four operations fluently to integers, fractions and decimals

thinking_lenses.rationale: Fluent operation across integers, fractions and decimals requires recognising that the same operational patterns (commutativity, associativity, distributivity, inverse) apply regardless of number type — the rules are consistent patterns.

Each arithmetic operation causes a predictable change — multiplying a fraction by a number greater than one increases its value, while multiplying by a proper fraction decreases it — and fluent reasoning requires internalising these causal effects.

clusters.rationale: Integer and rational number operations and prime factorisation/number theory are the foundational GCSE number skills. Both cover the core arithmetic fluency expected of all GCSE candidates.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.NS.A - Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions

clusters.cluster_name: Use powers, roots, surds, standard form and round to significant figures

thinking_lenses.rationale: Index laws are systematic patterns governing all power operations — a^m × a^n = a^(m+n) always holds, and extending to fractional and negative indices follows the same regular rule, making the pattern the computational engine.

Standard form and significant figures are tools for representing quantities at very different scales with appropriate precision — standard form encodes the proportional scale (order of magnitude) explicitly in the power of 10.

clusters.rationale: Powers/roots/surds (including fractional indices) and estimation/approximation (significant figures, error bounds) are the advanced number representation and precision targets at GCSE.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.EE.A.1 - Know and apply properties of integer exponents

clusters.cluster_name: Manipulate and factorise algebraic expressions including quadratics

thinking_lenses.rationale: Factorisation and expansion are inverse structural patterns — recognising that ax² + bx + c can always be rewritten as a product of linear factors (when it factorises) is the key insight, and the double-bracket pattern ax² + (ad+bc)x + bd is the generalised rule pupils must internalise.

Each algebraic form (expanded, factorised, completed square) reveals different structural features — the factorised form shows the roots, the completed square form reveals the vertex — so choosing the right form depends on what property you need to access.

clusters.rationale: Algebraic manipulation and factorisation (single brackets, double brackets, quadratics) is the foundational algebraic skill at GCSE upon which all equation and function work depends.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSA-APR.A.1 - Perform arithmetic operations on polynomials

clusters.cluster_name: Solve linear and quadratic equations and simultaneous equations

thinking_lenses.rationale: Equation solving is systematic if-then reasoning: each operation applied to both sides causes a predictable transformation that preserves equality, and selecting the right sequence of operations to isolate the unknown requires internalising these causal chains.

Quadratic equations can be solved by factorisation, completing the square or the quadratic formula — recognising which structural pattern (two identical factors, two different factors, irreducible quadratic) determines which method is most efficient is the key procedural insight.

clusters.rationale: Linear equations/inequalities, quadratic equations (factorising, formula, completing the square) and simultaneous equations are the core equation-solving cluster. C007 co-teaches with C008.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSA-REI.B - Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

clusters.cluster_name: Work with sequences, linear functions and non-linear graphs

thinking_lenses.rationale: Sequences are formalised number patterns — pupils derive the nth term formula by identifying the constant difference (arithmetic) or constant ratio (geometric) that drives the pattern, and extend this to express the general rule algebraically.

The gradient of a straight-line graph encodes a causal rate of change: for every unit increase in x, y changes by exactly m units — and for non-linear graphs (quadratic, exponential), the changing rate of change is itself what pupils must interpret and compare.

clusters.rationale: Sequences/nth term, straight line graphs (y=mx+c) and non-linear graphs (quadratic, cubic, exponential, trigonometric) are the function and graph cluster at GCSE.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSF-IF.C.7 - Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features

clusters.cluster_name: Understand function notation and apply graph transformations

thinking_lenses.rationale: Graph transformations encode precise causal rules: f(x+a) shifts the graph left by a units, af(x) stretches it vertically by factor a — each modification to the function notation causes a specific and predictable geometric effect on the graph.

Function notation (f(x), fg(x), f⁻¹(x)) reveals the structural architecture of composed and inverted operations — composite functions expose how independent processes chain together, while inverse functions expose the structural symmetry of reversing that chain.

clusters.rationale: Functions (notation, composite, inverse) and graph transformations (f(x+a), f(ax), af(x)) are the most advanced algebra targets at GCSE and form a distinct conceptual cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSF-BF.B.3 - Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x)+k, k f(x), f(kx), and f(x+k)

MA-KS4-D003.domain_name: Ratio, Proportion and Rates of Change

clusters.cluster_name: Use ratio and scale to solve problems and calculate percentage change

thinking_lenses.rationale: Ratio and scale problems at GCSE require fluent proportional reasoning — simplifying ratios, using scale factors in drawings, and calculating percentage change (with reverse percentage) all express multiplicative relationships between quantities.

Percentage change problems encode a causal multiplier — a 15% price increase causes the new price to be 1.15 times the original, and reverse percentage reverses that causal chain to find the original amount.

clusters.rationale: Ratio/scale (simplifying, dividing, scale drawings) and percentage change/financial mathematics are the applied proportional reasoning targets at GCSE foundation and higher.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.RP.A.3 - Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step problems

clusters.cluster_name: Apply direct and inverse proportion and interpret compound measures

thinking_lenses.rationale: Direct proportion (y ∝ x), inverse proportion (y ∝ 1/x) and compound measures (speed = distance/time, density = mass/volume) are all multiplicative relationships — the cluster requires pupils to identify the proportional structure and use it to solve problems.

The gradient of a distance-time or velocity-time graph encodes a causal rate — the rate of change causes the dependent variable to increase or decrease at a fixed rate, making graph interpretation a form of causal reasoning about rates.

clusters.rationale: Direct/inverse proportion (algebraic, graphical, numerical) and compound measures/rates of change (speed, density, gradient) are the advanced proportion cluster at GCSE.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.RP.A.2 - Recognize and represent proportional relationships

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate area, perimeter and volume using formulae for 2-D and 3-D shapes

thinking_lenses.rationale: Area of sectors, surface area and volume of cylinders, cones and spheres all require pupils to identify which formula applies based on the shape's structure — the geometry of the shape determines which measurements are needed and how they combine.

π links a circle's circumference and area to its radius through fixed proportional constants — understanding that C = 2πr means circumference is always proportional to radius is a key proportional relationship in this cluster.

clusters.rationale: Area/perimeter of 2-D shapes (including arcs and sectors) and volume/surface area of 3-D solids are co-taught (C017 co-teaches with C018, C019, C020, C021). These form the mensuration cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.G.B.4 - Know the formulas for area and circumference of a circle

clusters.cluster_name: Apply Pythagoras' Theorem and trigonometry to 2-D and 3-D problems

thinking_lenses.rationale: Pythagoras' Theorem and the trigonometric ratios are structural properties of right-angled triangles — the right angle determines a fixed relationship between the three sides (a² + b² = c²) and fixed ratios between sides and angles (sin, cos, tan) that pupils apply by recognising the structural configuration present.

Trigonometric ratios are proportional relationships: sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse is a fixed ratio for any given angle regardless of the triangle's size, which is why extending Pythagoras to 3-D problems requires pupils to identify the right proportional relationship across multiple right-angled triangles within a 3-D figure.

clusters.rationale: Pythagoras, right-angled triangle trigonometry (sin/cos/tan) and the sine/cosine rules (non-right-angled triangles) are the trigonometry cluster. C020 co-teaches with C017 and C019.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSG-SRT.C.8 - Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean theorem to solve right triangles

clusters.cluster_name: Prove and apply circle theorems, congruence and similarity

thinking_lenses.rationale: Circle theorems are structural properties of the circle — the equal radii and fixed centre create necessary angular relationships that pupils must prove, not just apply.

Proving circle theorems and congruence requires constructing a deductive argument from given geometric properties to a conclusion — each step must be justified by a named theorem or property, making this a formal evidence-based reasoning cluster.

clusters.rationale: Circle theorems (angles, chords, tangents) and congruence/similarity (proof and ratio application) are the formal geometry reasoning targets at GCSE higher. Both require proof skills.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSG-C.A.2 - Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords

clusters.cluster_name: Describe and apply geometric transformations and use vectors

thinking_lenses.rationale: The four transformations and vectors both describe systematic spatial change — column vectors encode translations by specifying exactly how the position vector of every point changes, and understanding vector addition reveals how successive transformations combine.

Enlargement by a fractional scale factor reduces a shape proportionally, and similarity requires pupils to reason about the constant ratio of corresponding lengths — making this cluster an intersection of geometric structure and proportional quantity.

clusters.rationale: The four geometric transformations and vectors (column notation, addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication) are grouped as the transformation and position cluster at GCSE.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.G.A.3 - Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations and reflections

clusters.cluster_name: Understand theoretical and experimental probability on the 0-1 scale

thinking_lenses.rationale: Probability is a proportional quantity on the 0-to-1 scale — expressing likelihood as a fraction of equally likely outcomes is direct proportional reasoning, and relative frequency converges to theoretical probability as trials increase.

Comparing experimental frequency with theoretical probability requires constructing an evidence-based argument — pupils must reason about whether a discrepancy is due to chance or suggests the theoretical model is wrong.

clusters.rationale: Basic probability and the probability scale (theoretical, experimental, relative frequency) is the foundational GCSE probability concept that all subsequent work depends upon.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.SP.C.5 - Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate probabilities of combined and conditional events using diagrams

thinking_lenses.rationale: Combined event probabilities involve multiplying fractions — P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B|A) — requiring pupils to reason proportionally about the fraction of outcomes that satisfy both conditions.

Tree diagrams and Venn diagrams are models of the probability space — they make the structure of the sample space visible and allow pupils to reason systematically about which outcomes satisfy given conditions.

clusters.rationale: Combined events/tree diagrams, Venn diagrams/set notation and conditional probability are the advanced GCSE probability cluster. C028 co-teaches with C029.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 7.SP.C.8 - Find probabilities of compound events using organised lists, tables, tree diagrams and simulation

clusters.cluster_name: Understand sampling methods and collect data appropriately

thinking_lenses.rationale: Data collection is the foundation of statistical evidence — understanding that a biased sample produces unreliable conclusions is the key argument about the quality of evidence and why systematic sampling methods matter.

Stratified sampling requires pupils to calculate proportional sample sizes for each stratum — if 40% of a population is female, 40% of the sample should be female, applying proportional reasoning directly to research design.

clusters.rationale: Data collection and sampling (random, systematic, stratified; bias identification) is the foundational GCSE statistics concept — understanding how data is gathered before it can be analysed.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math HSS-IC.B.3 - Recognise the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments and observational studies

clusters.cluster_name: Construct and interpret statistical diagrams and calculate averages

thinking_lenses.rationale: Histograms, cumulative frequency curves and box plots all reveal distributional patterns in data — the shape of a histogram, the steepness of a cumulative frequency curve, and the spread of a box plot each encode a pattern about where data is concentrated.

Choosing between mean, median and mode as representative averages requires evidence-based argument — pupils must justify which measure best represents the data for a given context, especially in the presence of outliers.

clusters.rationale: Statistical diagrams (histograms, cumulative frequency, box plots) and averages/measures of spread (mean, median, mode, IQR) are the core GCSE statistical analysis cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 6.SP.B.4 - Display numerical data in plots; summarise in relation to context

clusters.cluster_name: Describe and interpret bivariate data using scatter graphs and correlation

thinking_lenses.rationale: Correlation is a pattern in bivariate data — the overall direction and strength of the cloud of points on a scatter graph reveals whether a linear or other pattern links the two variables.

Interpreting scatter graphs requires pupils to construct and evaluate arguments about correlation — distinguishing correlation from causation and assessing how well a line of best fit represents the data are core evidence-based reasoning tasks.

clusters.rationale: Scatter graphs, correlation (positive/negative/none) and lines of best fit represent the bivariate data and relationship strand, distinct from univariate distribution analysis.
clusters.inspired_by: CC Math 8.SP.A.2 - Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables
